ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a workbook that corresponded to audio exercises, and we watched videos at home, as well.
We also watched videos again on our own and had a textbook, workbook, and course packet.
Online seminar

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned basically all the grammar of the French language!! This course focuses a lot on authentic comprehension (watching videos of native speakers) and is supplemented by exercises/grammar. I'm not fluent, but I can understand/express most things!
I had no knowledge of French before taking this course and in the span of a single semester I feel like I have learned many aspects of the French language and culture.
I learned a lot of French and learned about French culture.
I learned basic speaking, reading and writing in French

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is extremely well taught with close student engagement. I wish the course could have had some more speaking practice, which was difficult given the Zoom format. Honestly, though, it is very difficult to find a weakness.

I think the course is designed very carefully and allowed us to move at a very fast pace without feeling overwhelmed. The parallel between the story French in Action and the grammar we have been learning helped us to learn phrases faster and easier.

Strengths: Madame Sherak is incredibly helpful and was very supportive and encouraging throughout the semester. I also appreciated how flexible she was during the pandemic with assignments and scheduling.

Weakness: It can be a draining course since it is nearly 2 hours every day and the 1:30 PM time can eat up your day, but I liked being able to sleep in if I could and the breaks are very nice.

Perhaps more Zoom breakout rooms and more in-class exercises
Also having solid grammar review sheets whenever we learn a concept would be great

The course overall is great and will give you a strong foundation in French in a short period.  

The materials are dated, but they are also kind of awesome, and they are definitely still effective.  I do think that Yale should probably revisit the episodes and edit out some elements that have not aged well, including some problematic racial and gender stereotypes, or at least add material to address and own these problems.  At a point in the course we deviated partially from the French in Action materials, and I found it challenging to maintain the same study rhythm once we didn't use the FIA materials as consistently.  So, for me at least, it would have been a little better had we stuck fully to the program the whole class.  

I think having the course in the afternoon was great, and I wish that the second half of the intensive course were also offered in the afternoon.

The material could be updated to encourage more active engagement from the students. The storyline is outdated, so I didn't feel I was getting as much in terms of its cultural context as I could. Even conversations about what changed/what is different today would be interesting and informative.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, the course translated surprisingly well to the online format, especially for a language class. I got plenty of reading, writing, and listening practice. The only thing I wish we had was a bit more speaking practice, which was difficult over Zoom (we'd have to go into breakout rooms which is so much more difficult logistically than just turning to a partner and talking).

I think learning a language through zoom had its difficulties such as being able to hear the correct pronunciation of words or being able to imitate the instructor in order to be able to get words right but with a collective effort I think we overcame such problems.

I liked the flexibility in scheduling our tests because it made the class very accessible for students in different time zones and/or who had scheduling conflicts. I don't think this flexibility would have been the case in-person since we would all have to be on campus.
Language courses work fine online

The French in Action videos are very helpful as a learning tool. Yet, on Zoom when a video is shown through ScreenShare, there are a lot of freezes and for the purpose of engagement it wasn't very productive. I think the videos could be seen before class and there could be an alternative oral exercise related to the videos in class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Take this if you're serious about learning French and would get bored in a slower class like me...
I would definitely recommend this course to a student who wants to immerse themselves in the French language and culture at a fast pace, the results are very rewarding.
If you are passionate about language learning, this class is great and I am glad I took it intensively.
The course is advertised correctly - it is intense and you learn a lot of French in a short period of time.

This is designed as an intensive language course, so the workload might be greater than initially expected. But you get as much as you put in, so if you are interested in a solid and quick introduction to French, it is a good fit.
